product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: WAYNE N.
content: I LIVE IN A RURAL AREA AND MY INTERNET SERVICE IS VERIZON WIRELESS.  ALTHOUGH THE MANUFACTURER RECOMMENDS AGAINST IT BECAUSE OF THE BANDWIDTH REQUIREMENTS, I INSTALLED IT ANYWAY.  I ONLY NEED TO USE IT DURING SPECIFIC PERIODS, AND I ALWAYS KEEP CLOSE WATCH ON MY BANDWIDTH CONSUMPTION. I AM MORE THAN SATISFIED WITH THE RESULT.  BOTH THE CAMERA AND THE NEST SERVERS PERFORM EXACTLY AS ADVERTISED.  THEIR WEB PAGES AND CUSTOMER SUPPORT PERSONNEL ARE THOROUGH AND ACCURATE, ALTHOUGH I HAVE NOT HAD REASON TO CALL CUSTOMER SUPPORT AFTER I MADE THE PURCHASE. MY HOME IS SITUATED SUCH THAT THERE IS ONLY A SINGLE ENTRY POINT, THEREFORE THE CAMERA SEES LITTLE CHANGE DURING THE DAY.  WITH THAT, I USE ONLY ABOUT 21% OF THEIR ADVERTISED AVERAGE 200 KBPS UPLINK (I.E. I USE ABOUT 2.52 MBPS PER MINUTE) AT 720P.  AT 1080P, IT IS EVEN A SMALLER PERCENTAGE OF THEIR ADVERTISED AVERAGE, BUT 720P GIVES ME A CLEAR PICTURE WITH FACIAL RECOGNITION SO I HAVE NO NEED FOR THE HIGHER DEFINITION. THE MICROPHONE PICKUP IS EXCELLENT, AND I CAN HEAR AN INCOMING VEHICLE BEFORE IT EVEN COMES INTO VIEW.  THEIR DETECTION ALGORITHM DOES NOT TRIGGER ON SUCH EXTRANEOUS NOISE, THOUGH, BUT IT DOES PICK UP ON SUCH AS A DELIVERY VEHICLE STOPPING IN FRONT. I WOULD RECOMMEND THIS DEVICE AND SERVICE FOR USE WITH DOUBLE NAT (I.E. NO STATIC IP) WIRELESS IF, AND ONLY IF, YOU UNDERSTAND BANDWIDTH CONSUMPTION AND ARE WILLING TO RECORD AND ANALYZE YOUR USAGE.  THE UPLINK BANDWIDTH WILL VARY ACCORDING TO THE CHANGES IN VIEW OF THE CAMERA.
title: I AM MORE THAN SATISFIED WITH THE RESULT

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Jonathan E Rowe
content: Original review below, I've changed my review to 4 stars. I repurchased these about a year later and redid the wireless in my house at the same time. I'm now using the Ubiquiti UAP PROs and have good success with the Nest cams. They do occasionally go out, but for short periods of time. The new 5 day subscription is much more reasonable and I feel it's worth the cost. The only complaint I have now is the dashboards through any browser will on and off again have issues displaying real time video. This seems to be a known issue on the web. Both cameras went offline for 10+ minutes at a time all hours of the day. One of the cameras was 6 feet from the wireless router, and both had no significant interference. I couldn't find a solution that worked for me and was ultimately unhappy with the product. IF the offline issue had not been present, I would've been much happier with it, even with the ridiculous subscription fee.
title: Updated: Happy Now

author: TangO Bang0
content: These cameras are amazing! My roommate bought them without telling ANYONE in the house. They are set up outside two of our windows and look over the backyard and the side entrance. The best thing about these camera are 1) the video quality and 2) the audio quality The Video Quality: Amazing, we are able to keep a watchful eye on our cars parked in the backyard. You think you left something in your car? just log in and zoom in through your window to see if its on the front seat. These 300$ cameras saved our 5$ trashcan. Came out in the morning and couldn't find one of them after trash day. To the tapes we went! a little rewind action and boom we found the culprit. Megatron disguised as a trash truck rounded the turn to far and took our beloved trash can with him. A short skip 2 blocks up and there was the trashcan on the side of the road. Audio Quality: If you ever wanted to record a porno from outside the window these are perfect. You might not be able to see anything but you sure can hear everything that is going on in there! So next time your roommate brings a girl back from the bar give him a high five and check the tapes because you are in for a spanking good time. tl:dr - roommate didn't tell anyone and used them to spy on us

author: K. Moureaux
content: I bought two of these cameras to monitor my puppies.  I have one inside so that I can watch them when they are in the house and another outside so I can monitor them when they are outside.  I like having the ability to speak to them through the camera if only to divert their attention when they are doing something that I don't want them to.  I breed Border Collies and use it to monitor from my bedroom when the mom if getting ready to have her pups.  I'm always in there with her when she's delivering but I'd rather disturb her as little as possible when she's not in labor.  I then keep a close eye on the mom and pups as they are growing.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Jeremy Johnson
content: I had no problem with the packaging, install, user interface of the app or online, etc.  The issue that made it useless was the motion notifications.  During testing every single motion event was being recognized and recorded on the timeline.  But I was getting extremely sporadic notifications.  Seemed like one every hour or so.  When I told support they had me run through a million steps of uninstalling the app and resetting the camera.  This is just extremely poor support. If the events are getting recognized by the timeline and no emails are being sent out how can it possible be the app or the camera that's the problem?  It's by it's very definition a backend problem and the support reps just don't understand.  Looking over reviews problems with notifications have been an issue for years.  I got a used iPod Touch and downloaded Presence and it is absolutely perfect for detecting motion alerts.  I can dial in the sensitivity, schedule, and delay timers to my liking -- something I have to trust the all mighty Nest algorithm to do for me which just flat out doesn't work. Without good motion alerts this thing is essentially just recording for archival purposes.  And if that's all it's good for it's WAY too expensive because of the subscription service.  You're better off getting simple IP cameras and a NAS to function as a DVR.  Within a couple months it'll be cheaper to just do it that way.  Until they make the notification alerts more reliable and give more options on the notifications this is just not worth it.
title: Good camera.  Horrible motion detection notifications. Support is terrible.

The only thing it does now is show you a live stream of what's happening. With the Nest Aware free trial, the camera alerted me through the app when there was movement. I could immediately swipe and see a short clip of the aforementioned movement. Now I can't even see anything that has happened in the past, even 3 minutes ago! The app just freezes, nothing I had a pro alarm with before. I'm very disappointed with Nest. People bought the camera, they should be able to use it effectively. I would understand paying monthly for storage space, but paying for a functioning app? That's utterly ridiculous.
title: Camera Function Immediately Declines After Nest Aware Free Trial Ends

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Raymond L.
content: I did a lot of research before choosing the NEST cams.  And I really wanted to like them… But after using them (one indoor, one outdoor) for two months I simply cannot recommend.  It was a very frustrating experience and I wouldn’t buy if I had to do it all over again.  I tried to be as specific as possible to clearly define my exact issues and complaints.  Perhaps folks can suggest solutions/workarounds. The NEST app is not intuitive, difficult to navigate, and buggy --- to the point of being maddening when you first start using it.  My whole reason for going with NEST is that I thought the interface and features would be well-designed.  I was wrong.  I expected better from them.  Here are my main issues: 1.  After initial setup I had to delete & reinstall both my cameras because each was under a different ‘Home’.  If you use the “+” button in upper right corner it will add a 2nd Home…  you must go under 1st Home and choose “Add Product” under the tools pulldown in order to add additional cameras --- completely non-intuitive and not how most apps use the “+” button (eg.  TP-Link KASA app uses the same “+” button to add devices).  I would think that many users would fall into this same trap.  The only way out is to delete everything and start over.  Not a good way to start… 2.  NEST has ensured that this camera is not useful unless you pay for a subscription.  They do this by eliminating most of the features if you don’t have one (Zone motion triggers, person detection, see past video, etc).  Without a subscription you get ZERO video archive (some reviewers were saying it was limited to 3hrs or 12hrs, but this is false).  You only get a still picture of motion or generic sound alarm that occurred WITHIN THE LAST 3 HOURS, and the still may or may not actually have the image of what generated the alarm.  So if something happens in the middle of the night you won’t have a record of it the next morning.  They are trying very hard to make this camera equivalent to a live-only camera unless you buy their subscription! 3.  This is a cloud-based system, meaning that you have NO WAY to view any video unless sending to the cloud.  The bandwidth usage is completely outrageous!  I got an email from my internet provider after two weeks stating that I exceeded my quota of 300GB/mo.  I was uploading 5GB per day for ‘Medium’ quality!  For two cameras on high quality it consumes 600GB per month!  The app gives data/bandwidth requirements under “Quality and Bandwidth” pulldown, along with data hog warning – see screencap below.  This is ridiculous and will exceed most internet provider data plans.  So I can only turn on the cameras for a few hours each day and reduce the video quality --- so what’s the point of paying for “high def” cameras if I can’t use them?  And why pay even more for a subscription if I can’t fully utilize it?  And it isn’t possible to use cameras at all without sending to cloud, so now I am wishing I had bought something else… 4.  The NEST app provides integration with the TP-Link ‘KASA’ app, specifically:  When toggling between “Home/Away” mode you can trigger specific SCENES.  I have my TP-Link color LED bulb in Foyer turn GREEN or RED (RED=Away, GREEN=Home) anytime the NEST app sees that I physically leave my house (linked to my phone location) or someone manually toggles  “Home/Away” which also turns my cameras ON/OFF.  This manual toggle can be done either within NEST app OR the KASA app (icon added under devices—see screencap below).  In KASA, my wife can see the color of the bulb and shows what time I left (or arrived) at the house. - Note:  You can independently schedule cam ON/OFF times and this does not impact “Home/Away” status (ie.  lights do not change status) - Warning:  Periodically my indoor cam does not shut off when status changes to “Home”.  If I don’t notice right away, eats up a lot of my data quota! - Warning:  Every time you logout and log back in you will have to reconfigure the “Home/Away” settings – no way around this.  Bad software! - Warning:  The linkage between the KASA and the NEST app keeps breaking… doesn’t work as advertised.  I completely wasted my money… 5.  Software issues on the NEST side --- all day 1/4/18 I was unable to view live video or turn the cameras ON or OFF.  The cams were indeed working and could view past video from this timeframe.  After more than 1hr of troubleshooting I gave up.  Today everything is suddenly working properly again.  I figure it must have been an issue on the NEST side…  That is the problem with cloud-based systems, you are dependent on their systems to work as well as yours. 6.  Not a big deal, but every time you install a new camera (or delete and reinstall existing camera) as I have had to do numerous times, it gives completion error msg: “Oh No!  Something has gone wrong”, even though everything has installed correctly.  I really hate this software. In summary, the NEST cameras are not reliable and I will avoid NEST products in the future.
title: Buggy software and you must buy a subscription to make these cameras useful

I expect that more people have this problem then they do with the indoor version, so I would add an extra step in the setup: once you have it working indoors, take it outside and simply hold it where you want to install it and make sure it can still connect before you attach the bracket, drill holes, etc. The second minor problem is that the USB cable "locks" to the transformer with a cylindrical device that twists into the transformer. product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Moburner
content: Very good camera, but only with the subscription.  If you don't have the time or inclination to spend a lot of time to set up an outdoor camera, this is pretty easy.  However, unless you have a pretty good broadband connection and a fast wifi router, this is going to hurt.  I have DSL advertised at 10MBPS down/750KBPS up, and I couldn't get one to work properly without slowing everything to a crawl.  I have an excellent, recent wifi/router and each one of these cameras needs almost all of my upload capacity to work with the subscription, plus, it will all count towards the monthly cap, if you have one.  This wouldn't be such a problem if I could capture and store the video locally on my hard drive, but the Nest doesn't allow that.  Also, the advanced algorithms for motion detection, blanking, person recognition, video playback and storage require you to stream to their servers. I ended up getting SecuritySpy software [...] and dedicating an old iMac with a 4TB external drive and bought some IP PoE cameras instead.  I can add just about any kind of camera, including an iPhone, and see it on my desktop or view it remotely with an iPad or phone. There are a host of software providers for Windows as well, to do the same thing with a PC. Nest is excellent, but expensive, and you're going to be shackled to their subscription to get the good stuff. The subscription is probably a good value, if you have the capacity. I prefer wired cameras, but that probably isn't an option if you are renting.  All this one needs is an outlet and wifi. Bottom line; if I had good internet speeds, I'd probably go with them anyway, because of the advanced functions and ease of use. Not insignificantly, their customer service is excellent.
title: Easy to install, but requires paid subscription for features, must have broadband to work properly

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone

I know that seems like a odd complaint but in my mounting situation I needed a much smaller cable and there was no way to make the adjustment.  2) I didn't feel like the magnet was strong enough.  I bumped the installed camera twice and it fell off the mount.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Lizmarie G.
content: A free one month trial of Nest Aware is provided to the buyer when creating an account for the Nest Cam, which provides the camera all its useful features described here on Amazon. Upon ending the free month, I tested the camera without these subscription features. PROS: (1) Phone alerts when it hears sounds or senses movement, (2) Live video feed. That's it for pros. CONS: (1) When scrolling back to see previous recordings, only PICTURES can be seen, not video, (2) There is no facial or person recognition (the camera will alert "activity" or "movement" instead of a person, as it cannot tell the difference. This feature IS available with Nest Aware), (3) Only the previous 5 HOURS can be reviewed, and as mentioned before, through pictures, not video, (4) NEST AWARE IS LIMITED TO CERTAIN COUNTRIES All this is fine if you understand that the free features are enough for you. In my situation, however, I wanted to purchase the Nest Aware subscription, but my country (Puerto Rico) IS NOT SUPPORTED (although the free trial worked great, go figure!!!!) so I am stuck with an extremely expensive webcam. Please check if you are able to purchase Nest Aware in your country before buying the camera, as it is truly worth the money when you can access all its features.
title: Great Camera, Although Practically Useless Without Nest Aware Subscription (Puerto Rico and other unsupported countries, BEWARE)

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Ellen T Fusco
content: i love the video feed, quality wise, from this camera - the audio is near worthless for a couple of reasons: 1st as it has to upload to nest first, then download to my phone, that means two trips on the internet - which gives a 2 second delay. When i speak, it takes 2 seconds for it to make it to the camera at the front door, then after the visitor has heard my greeting, it takes 2 seconds for his response - not good, it gets confusing, and the visitor will repeat himself not knowing about the 2 second delay, and talk over what i'm responding.  2nd complaint - standing under the camera at the door, there's maybe 24" distance to the micro speaker on the camera - the volume is about the level of someone way down a long hallway talking to you in a normal conversation voice level. If there's a car going by, you're not going to hear it and the road is about 100 ft distance from the door. And that car noise masking the conversation is both ways, the visitor hearing or you hearing what they said. Then comes the fact that after selling you the camera, YOU DON'T GET THE MOTION OR SOUND ALERTS OF AN EVENT AT THE CAMERA IF YOU DON'T SUBSCRIBE TO THEIR EXPENSIVE CLOUD STORAGE WHICH JUST ADDS A DELAY TO THE ALERT BEING DELIVERED TO YOU. I only say expensive as it is the pricest service out there compared to their competitors. I will say the camera actually starts recording the motion event relatively close to the event commencing, ie recorded to the event video sent to your phone. It is recording 24/7 so you can always go online to your acct at Nest and review what occurred before the motion notification. now comes the real rub - a lot of folks on youtube have posted "workarounds" to enable a user to forego having to subscribe to the NEST Aware cloud storage service - and from comments under those youtube videos, apparently NEST puts it's engineers to work coding defeats to those workarounds - currently there are no working "workarounds" unless you're running windows 10 which i refuse to install - i work with videos and prefer Win 7. But even that workaround has a limited life expectancy. Maybe 10% of your customers are going to find and employ workarounds - and you actually spend resources & time looking for them and engineering "defeats" to continue your strong arming the customer into buying your cloud storage service?  Lame Nest, really Lame It's a shame - the video quality is excellent, the motion detection is excellent, the night vision is near worthless - maybe effective for 10' distance. Nest - charge me $250 for the phone and keep your $100/yr subscription for the 1st camera and $50 for each additional camera. Let a user record his/her video on their own computer - I spent $300 on a 1 TB SSD solely for video recording the camera. Fortunately i only purch'd one camera - looks like D-link will get the rest of my business below are two shots, one showing the night vision view, and i was being kind when i said 10' effectiveness - to give you a better idea of the same field of view there's a daytime shot from the same camera
title: wouldn't buy again on principle

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: TW
content: As a big fan of Nest products (own 12 products) this camera is certainly the most disappointing. The camera is supposed to distinguish people from pets (and roomba) but alerts me to my pets walking around even though I have it set to only alert me when there is a person in the room. This makes it no better than a regular nest cam despite a hefty price premium. This is troubling since a false positive makes me disregard alerts (and makes it annoying) rendering the "smart" features useless. I reached out to Nest and the customer service person tried to push Nest aware on me explaining that my settings are right but there is a bug that needs to be fixed. In the meantime I need to get Nest aware as a work around.  Not only is the camera not working as advertised but Nest's solution is to make me pay for a subscription to fix it. Very disappointing. If I wanted a camera that can't distinguish people from my roomba I would have saved money buying the cheaper version.
title: A "Smart" camera that fails terribly

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Amazon Customer - Vista, CA
content: I own Nest Thermostat and protects .  I finally decided to purchased the Nest Cam and Nest Outdoor Cam at the same time. (From Amazon and HDepot)  This is my first experience with WIFI cameras. Overall the setup was flawless. I had both cameras setup and functional within 10 minutes.  I’d recommend setting  up the Outdoor Cam near your WIFI router before taking it outside. Once setup easy to place and make operational , seems to have good day and night video on both cameras.  I do worry the Nest Outdoor is an target for theft .  There isn’t any way to secure the camera to the base.  The Outdoor is running on 40% WIFI signal strength the doesn’t miss a beat. The recording zones Nest needs a lot of improvement… outside zones are triggered from light shadows from cars driving by and by light changes from shadows,  even though the camera is not facing the street pointed at my front door, it sends email alerts when my porch light turns on each night and random  as passing.  I use Wemo to turn off the lights, using wemo schedules, you would thing these two items could alert each other.  My  Nest Cam inside the house has the same failure,  the camera zone triggers alerts when the room is dark and a light is turned on by wemo .  The inside camera is not facing the light  I’ve tried moving and reshaping  the zones. To no success.. I shouldn’t  have to work this hard for lights turning on.  Out of frustration I’ve deleted all zones.  Which leads me to trying to rationalize the value of recording if the zone performance  is this bad,  when I called nest their input is move the cameras  and after a long conversation I hear this is a common complaint ..my plan has been to install 2 more cameras.  I’ve nixed that idea  Nest is a long way from solving these zones and I’m concerned Nest will address it the same as the wave off function on my 6 nest protects.  Last Nest needs to address the  cost of recording. I'm considering sending the cameras back.
title: Cameras work great.. Zone feature is not as good as expected

I give up!!!  I'll get the Ring doorbell instead.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: K Lee
content: Nest customer support is a complete waste of time.  I can't judge the product as a whole from the one apparently broken camera that I received, but I can certainly judge the Nest customer support quality from my several conversations.  The camera is going back in the box and getting returned.  I would NEVER buy another Nest product again - I would have given the actual product a second chance but the customer support experience is not a glitchy, one-off failure.  The Google brand is tarnished by the poor quality of Nest support. I had two issues with this device - one, it kept flapping online and offline as it lost connectivity from a router that was less than 25' away.  Two, there is NO facility to block email notification of this event.  Customer support repeatedly could not understand that I had turned off all email notifications on my account and the camera itself yet I continued to get notification emails.  I made three or four calls to customer support over a period of a month and my issue had NO activity between my phone calls.  At each new call, there did not appear to be anything substantive recorded about the previous call since I got asked the exact same questions that I had answered in previous calls - the email notification seems like a stock problem, but I was experiencing an edge condition and customer support could not seem to wrap their head around that and write it in the ticket or sticky note where they track issues. During my last phone call, I talked with Dan and Dennis and then got transferred into a black hole.  Then called back and got Cassidy and then elevator music for several minutes.  Then I got JR who again started from scratch on the debugging and told me that there was no record of my first conversation with Nest in September and that no actual action had been initiated from my subsequent detailed conversation on 10 October.  Basically, customer support can answer a few basic questions but appear to be more interested in filtering out customer complaints than actually fixing problems with the product.
title: Nest customer support is a complete waste of time

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: KH
content: I have a number of Nest Cams and previous DropCams for indoors.  I have to say the setup is super easy and the picture is great.  Where this great camera is lacking is its horrible cable.  This is an outdoor camera and in many installations, like mine, I want to fish wires and hide them.  In my case I want to fish the wire through my attic soffit vent and then get power from the attic.  I was replacing an old Panasonic camera which went to a thin wired power pack and could easily splice an extension.  The Nest looks like it is wired to run my iron.  Also putting a large coupler after about 10 feet of wiring followed by about 15 feet of cable, which was nuts.  The USB end with its locking connector means I have to cut a 3/4" hole anywhere I want to run the wire and am limited to about 10 feet of cable since I don't want the 3" diameter coupler showing. In short beautiful camera, great software, horrible wiring.  At least sell it with alternate cabling?  If the cable was more outdoor friendly I would give it 5 stars.  Am I going to order another, yes, but that is because it has one of the best interfaces out there right now and I love the cloud recording for remote vacation homes.  Still hate the cabling :-(...
title: Terrible cabling design

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: C. Currie
content: Great product when it works! The ease of set up is great! I installed it and everything was fine. I have two other indoor Dropcams that I am happy with though high heat tends to fry the indoor cams fairly easy. I live in a place where it gets very HOT 100+ regularly. Even though the Dropcams are inside the house in the AC at around 77 degrees, the direct sun in a window sill will eventually cook them. Enter the outdoor security cam. A long awaiting member of the Dropcam family, I am happy to see they have taken things outdoors. That's where the happiness ends. I installed the camera and set it up. It ran flawlessly for 4 days. The temps were moderate, low 90s, no direct sunlight. On day 4, the camera had connectivity issues with my router (looks to be a common issue from the reviews and forums I have read). It's now day 6 and the camera turns on and off 10 minutes at a time - that is to say, 10 minutes live, 10 minutes off.. and so on. I suspect a heat issue as it occurs more often at night when the internal IR lights are on in the camera projecting outwards. Night time temps are in the mid 70s here. All other devices in the house work fine, including the other two Dropcams, so it's not a router issue or interference. I made an attempt to return the camera to Amazon, however they want to route me through tech support. Let me say, with a 3 month old baby in the house and 3 hours of sleep a night, the LAST THING I WANT TO DO IS TROUBLESHOOT A NEW DEVICE. Because I can't flat out return it, I am waiting for Techsupport to get my email so that they can run me through the gamete of BS. Where is AMAZON'S Flawless return policy that they had? If I had known this, I would have bought it locally where I can return it and exchange it for a new one without any trouble.
title: NEST - Please acknowlege the issue with this camera - Many MANY report the same problem.

Most likely, you will need high quality wifi extenders as well.  I would think for the price they would be better.  You will pay $100/yr for 10 day backup for your first camera and $50/yr for each additional one. It doesn't cap either. This adds up quickly!  I would look for other options if you want a security system.  Their indoor cameras are good for watching the dogs while you are away or making sure the kids are home from school.  Other than that, look for something else.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Work of Life
content: I preordered a couple of the Logi Circle 2 (directly from Logitech) after returning a set of the latest Nest outdoor security cameras (to Amazon). I have previously owned a set of 6 Logitech Alert cameras (which I loved, but they are no longer available). I am happy to say that the Circle 2 Indoor/Outdoor cameras are improvements over the current model Outdoor Nest cameras as well as the old Logitech Alert cameras. I ordered my two cameras along with the window mount adapters and installed them inside, looking out. Installation is super fast and super easy (as compared to both of the other camera systems mentioned above). My experience was a very simple plug and play. Unbox, plug in the cameras, download the app, connect to your network, customize your camera settings, then pop the camera into the stick-on window mount and you're done! Installation of each camera was less than 10 minutes (including unboxing, download the app and mouting to the windows). This was SO MUCH EASIER than Nest cameras which only offer magnetic and screw mount options (no window mount).  The Nest cameras are also nearly twice as big and much heavier as these new Circle 2 cameras, yet both offer same video quality and 180 view, same remote monitoring, same two way voice communication, etc. The Circle 2 cameras are smaller, lighter, more discreet and offer better mounting options. The Circle app is also a bit more robust than the Nest app. For example, the Logi Circle app allows you to adjust the monitoring areas. This allows you to set a smaller section of the viewable area to trigger movement alerts. This is great if you have pets and want to set movement alerts to only trigger for a doorway or window. The Circle app also offers a cool "day brief" feature that allows you to quickly scroll through all the movement events and alerts of the day. If you have the premium subscription (free for one month after initial set up), you can customize some settings of the Day Brief (if you only want to include "person" alerts). The Nest app lacks these features. Lastly, one year of Premium 31-day unlimited storage for the Circle 2 is only $99 per year/per camera versus Nest Aware which charges $300 per year per camera (at the time of this review). Again, it is the same quality video, but Logitech offers a much more reasonable cloud storage fee. Improvements I would like to see on the Circle 2 Cameras: 1) A feature on the app that allows us to adjust the recorded area of view. This feature was included in the Logitech Alert Commander software and I used it to edit out areas that didn't need to be recorded. I would like to see this in the Circle App as well. 2) With the window mounts, there are visible reflection "rings" from the window mount housing that show up on the video. Turning off the LED and the infrared greatly reduces these "reflection" rings, but doesn't eliminate them. I would like to see this improved. Even with this visual ring anomaly on the video stream, it is clear enough for my purposes (security) I am still a fan of the window mount. There is nothing else like it on the market so kudos to the Logitech engineers for creating this brilliant window mount. I hope they continue to improve it. 3) I would also like to see a local storage option for the Circle cameras. This was also part of the Logitech Alert cameras and Commander software that I had at my previous home. The cameras included Micro SD cards, the software would also allow you to assign storage on your local computer AND there were cloud storage subscription options. I really loved these features and am disappointed that the current standard in wifi security cameras is subscription based cloud storage and no local storage options. Granted, you can go in and manually download anything you want, but there are no automatic options (for Logitech Circle 2 or Nest cameras). All in all, I am thrilled with Logitech's newest security camera. Thanks for reading. I hope this review is helpful!
title: Nest Outdoor compared to newest Logitech Indoor/Outdoor Circle 2!

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Michael Wayne
content: If you've ever researched consumer-level outdoor security cameras, you know that the offerings have left a lot to be desired. Poor hardware and even worse software have pretty much defined the entire market. Commercial options are better, but they're also far more expensive and lack the basics of what I want in a home security camera (cloud recording and a decent smart phone app, to start with.) Fortunately, the Nest Outdoor Security Camera now exists. So far, I'm really impressed with it. The video and audio quality are great, but the best feature is the smartphone app (Android, in my case.) It's fast, it's easy to use, and it Just Works. This is a surprisingly difficult thing to get right, but Nest does. Scanning through hours of video is just as responsive and intuitive as watching the live feed or the last detected moment of activity. In contrast to this experience, a couple days ago I had to check the security feed at work. It involved installing a Java applet that's probably not from this decade and a phone app that crashed any time I tried to seek through the video. Installing the camera was painless, and the fact that I didn't have to run to the hardware store means they got the accessories right. The only complaint I have at this point is that the cables are too long. I actually have an outdoor outlet that's only a few feet from where I have the camera mounted, so I had to coil up the other twenty feet of cord. It's not ideal, but it's also not a big deal. To give a sample of the image quality, I've included a couple screenshots. The last screenshot is of the app's timeline, which gives previews of all detected activity (in this case, cars driving by.) As time goes on, I'll update this review with my experience relating to other aspects of the hardware and software. For now, I think it's an excellent buy and would recommend it to anyone looking for an outdoor security camera. 2016-10-01 update: I've had the camera running for a couple weeks now and it has not required a single adjustment or even the classic "disconnect power to restart device" move. I would appreciate more playback controls beyond 15-second skip within the app, but they are available via the web interface. Overall, still very happy with it. 2017-10-10 update: A year later and the camera's still great. No adjustments or power-cycling reboots to speak of, and the Android app has improved quite a bit. Short gif-like clips appear as notifications whenever activity is detected, and they usually tell me everything I need to know. I rarely watch the raw video feed now unless I'm looking for something specific. Over the last year it's recorded all sorts of random things -- a hit and run, property theft, and a neighbor who really didn't like being out in the rain. Well worth the $100/year price!
title: Finally, an outdoor security camera that gets it right.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Mark Bailey, Jr.
content: ---- Update 11/24/2016 ----- Nest made a few updates to their app recently that fixed the notifications issue I was having. They also rolled out some new features that make it incredibly easy to save clips from within the Nest app to the phone's camera roll. My wife and I have been VERY happy with this camera. The video and build quality is top notch in my opinion. In fact, because of user error in mounting the camera it actually fell from about 15 feet to the concrete below. The casing had a few scratches, but the glass protecting the camera was unblemished. The notifications from the app were fixed a few weeks after the camera was released and they have been flawless. It's also very user friendly. My wife tends to get frustrated with tech, but she has found this camera to be very easy to use. She loved the outdoor camera so much that we picked up a Nest Cam Indoor as a baby monitor. Has it met all of our expectations? Absolutely not, but many products don't. The app isn't always the most reliable. Connection drops from the camera from time to time, but only for a few minutes at a time. The $100 per year for 7 days of video history is a bit much in my opinion. None of those things are deal breakers. With all that said, we are very happy with the Nest Cam Outdoor. ---- Original Review ---- I would stay away from this camera until Nest works out some of the kinks. I've spent 3 hours total on the phone with their support trying to figure out how to get push notifications to work on my devices. The camera is useless in my opinion without the push notifications. Nest support says they are aware of the issue and their team is working to fix. I will update my review if the problem gets resolved, but at this moment I absolutely plan to return the camera.
title: Push Notifications Fixed! I Can Now Wholeheartedly Recommend This Camera

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Landon Dodd
content: Can not believe how easy this camera was to set up and get going. Literally takes about 10 minutes to install and start recording. The mounting system is utterly brilliant. Being able to mount the camera virtually any direction imaginable is wonderful to accommodate tricky building angles that other cameras simply can't deal with. Don't worry that it's magnetic. This magnetic hold is very strong and the camera isnt going anywhere. I didnt have a problem at all with the cables or the cable sizes that other people seem to have issues with. The USB portion of cable is about as big around as my ring finger. Simply drilling a hole, passing the cable through and then filling the hole with a rubber grommet and caulk makes the installation look nice and clean. I don't like micro USB connections (several other reviewers wished micro USB was used) due to water sealing issues- the connection on this camera solves that.  At one corner of my building, there is attic access for a plug. For the camera on this corner, I used a standard office desk cable pass through to run the cable into my attic. Looks very clean and leaves room for more cables in the future if the need should arise. Very happy with video and audio quality- talking at a normal volume the camera easily captures sound and you can tell what's being said. Video quality is great with a nice 130° field of view. Yoy can see a LOT with this camera. Night vision doesn't blow me away but it's adequately usable and doesn't fall behind the other cameras available. The monthly subscription is kind of steep imo but we don't have a choice but to pay for it if we want to keep and view recorded footage. The nest app is GREAT and I love having all of my cameras and thermostats in one app. The "Spaces" feature makes using the cameras a joy. Also love the fact that I can talk to people via the camera- One of my favorite features. This is one of the best outdoor security cameras available right now so if you're in the market for one, this is what I'd go with. If you're already in the Nest ecosystem, this is a no-brainer. Extremely high quality piece of hardware that's well built and performs wonderfully. It was worth the wait.
title: Excellent Camera- Worth the Wait.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone

content: Love Nest cameras! I have them outdoors for different things. Even in my chicken pen so I am alerted of a preditor. Very easy to set up. Only draw back id the $ yearly  for the service, I didn't think it was a lot though.
title: GREAT Worth every penny!

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: CLib
content: Not sure what Nest was thinking when they designed the cable connection for this camera. I planned ahead and put electrical outlets close to where I was going to install the cameras. Now I have 25' of cable with a fat, ugly adapter in the middle to span a distance of around 2 feet. Hey, I get it. I know a lot of people will be putting these cameras up high and running the cable to a typical outlet near the floor/ground. But why not offer a couple of different cable lengths? Anyway, a good product gone bad by lack of thinking by the designers and engineers.
title: Great Camera, Awful Cabling

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Tim F
content: I’m really disappointed with these cameras. By all rights they should be the best in class home security cameras. However problems I’ve encountered with their software, hardware, and customer service stop me from recommending these to anyone. I bought an outdoor and indoor camera to create a basic home security setup, and intended to use the indoor camera as a baby monitor in a few months. I set up both cameras and was pretty amazed by the quality of video, thumbnailing, and alerting we were getting. However I had a problem with the “home” and “away” setting. I wanted alerting only to happen when the cameras were set to “away”, and to just passively record when we were home. This was very flakey, and I spent about an hour debugging it with Nest customer support. Resetting cameras would occasionally allow the alerting to function properly but it would immediately get out of sync. Look online - apparently this issue has existed for months. Now, every time we or anyone would walk near either camera I would get notifications and emails. This goes from mildly irritating to infuriating really quickly. So, I turned off alerts altogether. This removes about 30% of the value for me. My second issue is my indoor camera would drop offline for 20 minutes at a time every week or so. I reached out to nest support (again) and ended up with a support tech who argued with me for some time that a) it wasn’t a big deal and b) just move it around some more to see if it still happens. Trust me it’s a big deal if a baby monitor isn’t reliable. I got a lot of attitude from this guy. Since I had my two cameras equidistant from my wifi (with line of sight) and only one was dropping it seemed clear to me there was a problem outside of positioning. When I suggested I would instead just return the camera the tech said instead he’d do a camera swap. Great! Except he shipped it to the wrong address with a different name (but close enough to my name that I felt like he was griefing me). OK, I reached out a third (!!!) time to support to correct the address, this time over the phone. This tech was somewhat upset that the address was so badly botched and assured me she would get it fixed. I’m sure she tried, but it wasn’t fixed. Fortunately it went to my neighbor who I am friends with, so I at least got the camera. I sent the old camera back a few days later (weeks ago) via the included USPS sticker. Now I’ve gotten multiple harass mails saying they will need to charge me if they don’t get it. It’s been weeks in transit USPS ground…and they have the tracking number. Seriously, what the heck? I now have my new indoor camera, which has the same 20 minute dropout issues (this time in the same location my other, working fine, outdoor camera was in for months). And I can’t use alerting. And at this point I’m too weary to contact Nest again for anything. I paid for a year of service for each camera, which I will just grin and bear. But the software, hardware, and customer service of this product just leaves a bad taste in my mouth.
title: Really disappointed with these cameras

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Megan dowdy
content: I honestly can't believe this sort of business practice is even legal in America. Let me explain what you'd be experiencing upon purchasing this camera. First you receive it in the mail, and excitedly you begin setup.  You realize pretty quickly if you didn't know when purchasing, that it is a wired camera. A bright WHITE camera with a bulky bright white cord (with a bulky mid-line power block in the middle of it.)  So your new camera won't be blending in with your house because even if you have a white house the face of the unit is a contrasting glossy black.  Also, since the cord has to either be plugged in indoors or have some sort of weather proof outlet available, you will most likely be making a trip to the hardware store. Okay, you're all set up.  Time to check this thing out right?  Well you'll quickly discover that unless you're defending your home from the most idiotic burglars ever, you'll be getting nearly zilch because the camera just plain DOES NOT record in 1080p (even after changing settings.)  I dont know if there is some seedy loophole or something but when I watch television in 1080p I know I can read license plates that are more than 20ft away from the camera. Maybe you're okay with that so lets move to the worst part.  The app that lets you utilize your camera and view events almost never works well, and you'll find yourself reloading.  You might even pop on over to settings after being prompted about this "Nest Aware free trial" that you've been given...To your dismay you'll find that unless you pony up another $100 a year (or 10$ a month) minimum, your new nest camera will, in just 30 short days, turn into a useless piece of trash that takes "snapshots" of events (which means you MIGHT catch a burglars rear end as hes coming or going,) and these snapshots are only available in the cloud for 3 hours. TLDR; you'd be purchasing what is essentially extortion in a box unknowingly.  cant believe these things have such high ratings.
title: Extortion in a box

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Mg
content: The product everyone's been asking for since Dropcam originally came out is finally here!  Installed it today and it was fairly simple; The power cord is 15ft and the usb cable linked to the power adapter / cord is another 10 ft.  The thing I was most worried about was that since this was on a magnetic base it would be fairly easy to steal.  Luckily they include some cable retainers that screw into the exterior of your home which should make it a bit harder (you could even get a security bit set if you really wanted).  The other thing I was worried about was the fact that this is actually plugged in to an outdoors and someone could easily just unplug it; went to home depot and installed one that you could lock / zip tie.  So far from what I can tell the wi-fi is improved and is working great outdoors and video quality is on par with the nest-cam.  Will probably be adding a few more if they go on sale come black friday.
title: Finally an outdoor version!

content: I haven't even installed my camera yet and am annoyed.  I live in the Phoenix area where every summer we have highs 115°F+.  So imagine my surprise when I purchase an OUTDOOR camera and find its maximum operating temperature is 104°F.  I have to question the design of an outdoor surveillance camera that doesn't even meet the operating temperature range of its subjects (humans).  I wonder if I can get a 15% refund on both the purchase and subscription price for those times during the year when the camera needs a break...
title: We don't all live in Silicon Valley...

author: Vic P.
content: The camera is a great piece of hardware.  But to take advantage of historical replay you must subscribe to Nest Away, a recording service that should provide 10 days of replay for an annual cost of $100 for the first Nest camera and $50 for each additional.  Without this service, you will not have access to recording past 1 Day and no ability to record locally to your own computer or hard drive. The Nest Aware service is unreliable and the support is worse!!  I have had days not recorded when I really needed to review and Nest is unable to explain.  They are sympathetic to my disappointment and they expect Nest Aware to funtion properly as well, but it does not.  Nest Aware is key to the camera's usefulness, so given unreliability of the service I would not recommend this product from Nest.
title: Poor Nest Aware Reliabilty - Ruins a Great Camera

I called back and spoke with the same "manager" (named Brett) who offered me the same discount of $60 and kept me on hold for about 30 minutes. He then said he couldn't connect me to a manger at this time and that someone would have to call me back (yeah right!). I then refused to get off the phone and he then hung up on me. I guess I should just cough up my $20 a month for my subscription every month and keep quiet, right NEST?

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
content: It was necessary for me to connect and disconnect from WiFi for several days to find the location that worked properly. I have two of these cameras now. One connects through a window direct line of sight to main wifi 8 feet away. The other is about 40 feet away near the driveway using a wifi extender from main wifi. This product is beautifully packaged with everything you need to make it work. I also have a RING camera as a doorbell. The quality of the picture on the Nest camera is much better. The network service $100/yr for 1st camera and $50/yr for 2nd camera is fast and easy to use. From Hawaii we were able to watch a snow storm at our house and see that there were no foot prints around our house.
title: Very Reliable Camera

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Richard Sonnen
content: The camera itself is well-designed - solid construction, good image quality, acceptable sound quality, great packaging design.  Pretty much what you'd expect from Nest/Google. The mounting system is novel (a strong magnet that allows you to easily point the camera) but a poor choice for an outdoor camera.  The unit would be trivial to steal or knock down in many mounting scenarios.  I'd be much happier if there was a real connection to the mounting surface. The fatal flaw is the cable system.  Long captive cable to a standard USB connector, a puck-sized power transformer, then another long captive power cable to a standard two-prong plug.  Neither has any means to swap out an appropriate-length cable. No matter where your power source is in relation to the camera mounting point, you will have a coil of USB or power cable to hide somewhere.  This camera is intended to be permanently mounted, so that's not a trivial design error.  It will eventually annoy me enough that I cut the USB cable and re-terminate it to the correct length for my installation, but that's not exactly something a buyer should have to tackle. The phone app is reasonably well put together, though the newest version seems a bit laggy.  The camera display screen seems to be preoccupied with selling you their cloud storage add-on at the expense of usability. I went with the Nest because I have an old Dropcam, Thermostat, and a few Protects, so I'm already invested in their ecosystem.  If you aren't, I don't see a lot to recommend this one over its competitors.
title: Decent camera, terrible cable design

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Bob Jones
content: *** See bottom of review for all updates *** This is my second Nest product.  I have a Dropcam pro installed in the house and this Outdoor Nest Camera installed overlooking my driveway, carport entrance and front of house.  I have a third Outdoor Nest Cam on order for the back yard. I am willing to pay $99/year for the first camera and $50/yr for the second one (for 10-day recorded video).  I have a third camera for the back yard and know I will pay another $50/yr for that one.  That works out to $200/yr for three cameras, or $0.55/day.  I have cut the cord on cable TV and so really this expense is not that bad.  The initial cost of the camera seems kind of pricey, but the build quality of this outdoor model is impressive. Many people discuss their concerns with the magnetic mount and the likelihood that the camera might be stolen.  I have no such fears.  I just installed it high enough to eliminate that worry.  By the time they get to the camera, I will have a good shot of them anyhow.  And once I inform Nest of the stolen camera, it will be of absolutely no use to them anyhow. Setup was super easy and best done with an iPhone or Android phone (as opposed to a desktop computer).  It literally only took me about a minute to get it connected to my WiFi and start streaming images. The image quality (day and night) is very good compared to other cameras I have used (see examples). Because we have brick walls I was afraid that the camera would have a hard time grabbing my WiFi signal.  My router is on the opposite side of the house.  I am happy to report that there have been no connection issues so far - and the video stream is solid. I had to run a length of extension cord to the camera (even though it comes with about 25 feet of cable). The main issue I have are false positives on the alerts.  The alerts I have set up send me frequent false positives thinking that a person is in view of the camera.  Flashes of light or moving shadows also cause many false positives.  I am still working on my settings to find the perfect balance. So far the camera does what it is supposed to.  And it is great being able to capture video clips and share them.  We will see how this camera survives the winter, summer and elements in general.  But I am impressed so far and I know Nest will always be improving their detection algorithms - they have a way to go on that score. FIRST UPDATE:  Well I have had all three cameras running (two Outdoor models and one Dropcam for inside) for several months.  I am pleased to report that everything is running fine.  I especially like the phone app (I use an iPhone 5s) and it works great and is very useful.  I would say that I have not been able to get the "Home/Away Assist" working.  This would eliminate me getting alerts when I am home by detecting when my cell phone comes and goes.  I did some online research and gave up after seeing that a lot of other people are having the same issue.  Hopefully Nest can get that problem figured out and push a firmware update.  I also get way too many false positives.  Our dog looks like a person to the algorithm.  Car lights and moving shadows are also the bane of this product.  And I do have a few inconsistent wifi connection issues with the camera farthest from my router - but it only pops up every now and then.  So I am happy 8/10 with the product and looking forward to improved detection algorithms in the future.  $200/yr for 3 cameras seems steep.  But I will pay it until a better option comes along. SECOND UPDATE (8 months later):  Still working like a charm.  Wifi connection remain strong, even with my most distant camera.  I'm not using any Wifi extenders.  Sometimes something interferes with the wifi on my most distant camera (who knows what it might be), but it seems to only last a few minutes periodically per every other week.  Recording is rock solid.  I still wish the algorithm was better at filtering out birds and flashes of light and blowing snow, but whatever.  I will be buying one last camera to complete my security system.  Not looking forward to paying another $50/yr for a 4th camera.  But I guess I will until a better more affordable option comes along.  I am slowly building up quite a collection of clips that I am saving as bloopers.  Slipping on the ice.  Falling down the stairs.  Etc.  Good times! THIRD UPDATE (4 YEARS LATER):  Still working.  I have two Nest Outdoor Cams and one old indoor Cam.  They all still work like a champ.  I just bought a 12-LED IR floodlight for my outdoor cam in the back yard.  I don't know why I waited so long.  What a difference!  Now I can actually see what is going on at night.  The built in IR LEDs on the outdoor cams are pretty weak.  I just don't know why it took me so long to realize this.  Also I wish resolution was higher for both day and especially night.  I am starting to look at 2K and 4K cameras and might make the switch once I read some reviews.  I just seems like the quality and clarity of the Nest Cams could be better and maybe they aren't keeping up with the competition.
title: *** 3rd Update *** (4 years later - Aug 2020)

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: emtiv334
content: Neat idea.  Horrible implementation! I bought two of these and installed them on my house.  The first few months, they worked pretty well besides having issues when the sun would get in just the right spot in the sky and it would be hard to see anything on the cameras.  Not because the camera was pointed at the sun, but the light in the yard would just fall exactly right and everything on the camera would just kind of grey out. Fast forward a few months later.  I started getting TONS of alerts a day.  Literally 200+ alerts.  Everything sets these off.  Bugs flying in front of them, a cloud goes across the sky.  The sun comes up, the sun goes down.  A bird chirps in the yard.  A raindrop falls from the sky.  A snowflake.  Literally ANYTHING sets these off. I contacted Nest to complain about this and ask to return the cameras for a refund because I am very dissatisfied with them.  According to Nest, these alerts work off color changes.  Anytime something in the viewing angle of the camera changes color, Nest determines that means there needs to be an alert.  I didn't know that when I bought them, or I would not have bought them.  Like I said, neat idea, but horrible implementation.  Now I'm stuck with $500 worth of security cameras that alert me every time a bug passes gas in the yard.
title: Neat idea, horrible implementation, and even worse customer support.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: The K
content: So far this is the outdoor camera I've been looking for. I had every intention on buying 3 Hikvision 3 megapixel outdoor cameras since the night vision is so great on that particular camera. My problem was recording and storing video. I'm a normal home owner who just wants a camera installed to watch over my vehicles at night and keep an eye on my front door when I'm not at home. The problem with this kind of set up is I would either have to purchase a DVR for an additional $100-$150 and have the ability to record and store 2 months of footage. Or I'd have to run a server off my PC at all times. Which leads me to the next issue I was planning on dealing with. After purchasing all of this great equipment, getting it installed, spending hours in my attic running cable to the DVR and getting the web server set up, I still have to make the entire system easy enough for my wife to use. With the Nest Outdoor Camera I don't have to worry about that. I pre-ordered the camera figuring I could just return it if I didn't like it. The box came just like my Nest Thermostat and Nest Protect did, well packaged and ready to install. Installation was easier than I thought. I opened my cell phone app and added the camera, scanned the QR code and no more than 10 seconds later had video set up and recording.  My wife's phone updated about 30 seconds later. I mounted the little bracket the magnetized base attaches to, and routed the USB cable into the hole I drilled leading to my attic space. The next part was the worst part of the whole process but this has nothing to do with the system itself. I climbed in my attic (which was currently 120 degrees of the most viscous South Texas air you can find) and made my way to the wire I fished through the hole. I used the supplied wire clips to attach it to the roof rafter (it's low voltage wire so this is kosher) which I then routed to the area of my attic that my home builders were kind enough to install a 120 outlet in. Once I got that situated it was only a matter of plugging the power in and getting my rear out of there before the complimentary installation heat stroke was delivered. That's it...Well, not exactly, I did put some silicone caulking around the hole I drilled. A tip for you self installers out there, pull the cord out 3 or 4 inches and wrap 1 or 2 layers of regular packaging tape around the cable, that way when you seal the hole you won't get the cable all goopy. Video quality is fantastic. It's slightly less clear than the Hikvision during the day, but comparable at night. As a normal home user, this is more than adequate for my household. As great as this thing is, there are a few negatives I'd like to point out. - The App constantly reminds you to upgrade your free trial to the paid version of Nest Aware, it's a bit intrusive - I would have liked the magnetic base to have the ability to route the cable directly through it so none of the cable is exposed, a small gripe - 10 day monitoring is a bit pricey at $15 a month for 2 cameras, 30 day monitoring is out of reach for some home users ($45 a month for 2 cameras) - As far as I know, you're locked in to using the Nest Aware for recording and storage of video - Color options would have been cool, I assume they went with white to keep the unit as cool as possible -The magnet base is awesome. I do worry in the Houston heat that the camera could begin to droop or slowly slide down over time. Overall I don't see a scenario where I'd return these cameras. Well worth the $400 investment. **9/23/16 UPDATE** For my second camera installation, I decided to try the POE route. I purchased an 8 port POE injector and 2 USB POE splitters, set up took about 10 minutes. Works perfectly.
title: A perfect outdoor camera option for any home user **Works with POE

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: cm
content: I would stay far away from this Nest product.  Nest was purchased by Google and now once you switch over to their service, they will do a bait and switch on you.  At first, the service started out as $100 a year for 1 camera, $50 more for each additional cameras.  Then, they dropped the subscription to paying $80 a year for 2 cameras.  Now, since Nest was purchased by Google, you will have more cameras added for one price but the service is limited.  If you choose Nest aware subscription, you will pay $60 a year for 30 days of video event history with only recording when something happens.  There are huge gaps in the recordings and if someone comes to your door, within that lost gap recording, you will not know.  If you want 24/7 recording, you will have to choose the the Nest Aware Plus subscription, which will cost you $120 a year.  Once you switch over to Google, there is no switching back.  Everything is at Google, even with the purchases of all Nest products.  Notifications and recordings were better when Nest owned the products, now it is a nightmare with Google owning the company.
title: Do not Buy

For e.g:  if you are using wifi range extender with same SID/password as your base Wifi router and in case there is any interruption, then the camera gets confused which router to connect and it disconnects permanently. There are other bugs aswell where the camera recovers only 90% of the times after interruption due to wifi interference in crowded situations. Also we are unable to launch the video directly in the mobile app when a motion is detected and notification appears on the mobile phone. We need to relaunch the mobile app then go the history of saved videos and watch it from there. They are just looting money from customers in the name of "Nest Aware" subscription. These are the days where cloud solutions have become very cheap and common options and still Nest wants to squeeze the money out of customers. We have many others cameras in market like Netgear Arlo & OCO 2 while provide similar if not even better security options as Nest with much better/free cloud subscriptions. This camera is not better than a dummy camera if we don't pay the monthly subscription.
title: Used it for 1 month, lot of bugs & looting money from customers in the name of "Nest Aware" monthly subscription

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: John Ferguson
content: This camera is weather proof, in a plastic-like housing, and uses a magnetic base around which it can be oriented to the angle you require for viewing.  The previous indoor Nest Cams could be adapted for outdoor using a protective housing with a heat sink at the back.  However, I noticed that this attenuates the sound that is picked up.  The outdoor Nest Cam has a louder monitored sound. The USB cable is about 15' and connected to the AC adapter which is intended for outdoor mounting too (has a mounting clip).  The AC side has a 20' cord that is moulded into the PSU (i.e. is not unpluggable like the USB side), of it is is too short, you'll need an extension cord.  There as clips to hold the wires in place, but I used small conduits available from Home Depot to enclose the entire cable. The USB cord at the camera end is also moulded into the body (cannot be unplugged like the original indoor cams). The angle of view is 130 deg wide and the 1080p/720p quality is excellent. You can see vibrant colors and smooth motion and hear what is going on outside. The best features are in the Nest software, which has been updated recently to improve detection of motion, and discerning whether that motion is from a human, or non-human (e.g. vehicle).  You can define activity zones using polygon drawings on your viewed scene to identify where you want to notified of activity. The number of false notifications has been greatly reduced with the updated software.  However, sharp and sudden shadows (from cloud movements) or bright lights turning on at night (from nearby motion sensors) may sometimes be interpreted as motion with false notifications. A Nest Aware subscription is to record video/audio is available for 10-day and 30-day history.  This is useful for his security monitored areas where you may want to retrieve a record of activity.  The software also takes snapshots of activity in a time line, in addition to the the continuous video/audio history.  So, if you get a notification, you can quickly find the time stamp and as you scroll the time line you'l see activity that was snapped. I find this useful to know when the mail has been delivered, as it takes a snapshot of the van in an activity zone.  I can also see when packages are delivered to the front door and retrieve them right away. I highly recommend this camera for outdoor home security and surveillance.  It works on wifi and and has a longer USB+power cord to reach most outdoor sockets.
title: Great camera for outdoor surveillance

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Mr Night
content: This camera pictures looks really good, including at night.  Easy of setup depends on the availability of outlets in your attic, which for me was a huge pain and next time I would go with ethernet power, but I'm willing to accept that trade off. Where this camera really fails is integration with the app.  First off, if you have an Android phone (like, you know, a few million people), the intercom feature on the cameras does not work.  So much for talking to someone through the camera when they are at the door. Much worse, is that they keep sending constant alerts of movement even when you turn off security because you are working in the yard.  The alarm system has settings for "away, home and guarding, and off."  Which makes sense, because at night you want to know if someone is lurking at the door while you are protected. But the cameras only have settings to send alert on "Always, No Ones Home, Never."  Given that this system was supposedly made all by one company (a huge selling point in their adds), why wouldn't the cameras have the same settings as the app?  Do the people in different departments not talk to each other? Not to mention that the things barely work if you don't pay a pretty hefty monthly fee.  For iPhone prices, you would expect an iPhone level of planning.
title: Bad integration with app, dissapointing for the most expensive of systems

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: EES
content: While we enjoy the ability to monitor the house while we are out, the issue of video lag is getting worse every month. We have the thermostat, doorbell, and outdoor IQ's. All cameras have taken longer and longer to load. I spoke with customer service and they just lie non-stop. They told me no one esle has been having problems. There are numerous forums about  this online. Afterking with two neighbors, I found that they are having the same issues whether at home or out of the house. Their servers are getting worse as the months go by. I am currently researching other home monitoring systems. I would not recommend.
title: Nest knows they have MAJOR lag issues.

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone
author: Happy consumer
content: I purchased this camera about 2 months ago for security reasons. It is a two pack and very worth the money I paid. I think the cameras are nice well made and the video quality is good- I usually look at it from my phone so your phone will have a lot to do with this as well. I felt it was easy to hook up and run and as a techniligically impaired person it really is easy to use!  The only real con is the night video is not the best and positioning on my house was a little difficult but again that is my house not the camera. The email alerts are nice but it does pick up passing cars and people who just walk by- this doesn’t bother me as that is what the cameras are for- my opinion only!  If your looking for a camera that is good quality, for home security look no further...
title: Well worth the money!

product: Google Nest Cam Outdoor - Weatherproof Outdoor Camera for Home Security - Surveillance Camera with Night Vision - Control with Your Phone

content: Many false alarms on motion detector mode even with tightly set detection zone. Difficult to pause playback. Overall, if this is as good as it gets, only marginally useful. 5-day subscription archive at $50/yr per device.
